result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (2nd) and Operating w/ PAC (2nd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (2nd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (2nd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Heriberto Reyes-Castro was found guilty of OWI (2nd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Heriberto Reyes-Castro was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Heriberto  Reyes-Castro
parties.address: 2430 W Mineral St Upper, Milwaukee, WI 53204

parties.name: Jackson County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: To be paid monthly during term of probation.  Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.    If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Defendant to be subject to random alcohol and drug testing by his agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Credit for 7 days if revoked.

May apply for early discharge after 12 months, if agent recommends.

timeConds.notes: All but the first 5 days stayed on the condition the defendant successfully completes probation including alcohol and other drug treatment.  Find has been served.

Proof of attendence at AA meetings

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, with Attorney Luening.  Interpreter E.S. previously sworn.  Defendant plead guilty to Count 1, OWI 2nd and Count 3, Obstructing.  Count 2, dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Count 4 dismissed by operation of law.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the counts he plead to.  Prior OWI confirmed with the defendant.    Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the pleas. Deportation warnings given.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of OWI 2nd, contrary to 346.63(1)(a) and Obstructing, contrary to 946.41(1).  

State recommending Act 100 probation. 18 months. .18 PAC.  $450.00 fine, plus costs.  15 days jail, all but first 5 days stayed on the condition the defendant successfully completes probation and includes alcohol and other drug treatment.    EMP allowed.  Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.  12 month DL revocation and IID.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan. 12 months probation on the obstructing charge.  Concurrent.   If no probation, $1429.00 fine and costs.  15 days jail.  12 mo DL rev. & IID.   Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.  Defense agrees with probation recommendation.  Serve jail in Milwaukee.  

Court ordered:  sentence withheld, 18 months probation on Count 1.  $450.00 fine, plus costs.  15 days jail, all but first 5 days stayed on the condition the defendant successfully completes probation and includes alcohol and other drug treatment.    Find time served.  Credit for 7 days, if revoked.   Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.  12 month DL revocation and IID.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan. 18 months probation on Count 3. Concurrent with Count 1.  CC.  DNA sample and surcharge.  May apply for early discharge after 12 months, if agent recommends.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Subject to random alcohol and drug testing.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.
Plea/sentencing hearing on August 4, 2016 at 09:45 am.
Status conference on June 13, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

No appearance by defendant or counsel.  Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Court states there was an authorization of file.  Court calls the defense counsel Matthew Luening's office.  Attorney Luening states he's received an offer from the State and he has sent a counter offer but hasn't heard back.  DA Fox will check if he missed that email.  Attorney Luening will call DA Fox tomorrow.  Court sets another STC for 6-13-16 at 3:00.  Judge will need to know if there will be need for more than 1 interpreter for trial and how many days.  Attorney Luening to call in.

Per telephone call with Atty Luening 's office this date, atty to obtain from his client and file with the Court prior to the scheduled STC, an authorization to appear on his client's behalf at the rescheduled STC date, so no interpreter will be needed. Atty Luening will be appearing by phone for that STC.
Status conference on June 6, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Defendant's Motion for Adjournment

Pre-trial conference on May 4, 2016 at 10:00 am.
Status conference on May 23, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Reading of the complaint waived.  NGP entered by defense.  NGP entered by the court.  PTC set for 5/4 and STC 5/23 at 3 pm.
defendant appeared voluntarily.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Luening.  Interpreter called.  Sworn by Clerk.  mariana kralew.  Warrant quashed.  Bond reinstated.
to Stay Bench Warrant

An attorney from Milwaukee called and will have this case scheduled to address the warrant.
